questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents to the gynecology clinic seeking long-term contraception. She has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea.She has no significant medical history and is not currently taking any medications. After discussing various options, she is interested in intrauterine devices.Which of the following is the most appropriate intrauterine device (IUCD) for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of IUCD

Examples

Composition

MOA

Duration

Advantages

First Generation

Lippes loop

Non medicated made of polyethylene or other polymers
  • Leads to foreign body reaction producing sterile inflammatory responses

10 years
  • Long duration
  • double "S" shape closely fit the contours of the uterine cavity, reducing the chance of expulsion

Second Generation

 

(Copper IUCDs)

Copper T 380

Copper wire wrapped around the IUCD
  • Releases copper ions which are spermicidal
  • Impairs sperm motility and viability
  • Interfere with the capacitation of sperm

10-12 years
  • Long duration
  • No hormones involved
  • Suitable for those who cannot use hormonal contraception

Third Generation

 

(Hormonal IUCDs)
  • Mirena
  • Progestasert

Levonorgestrel
  • Releases levonorgestrel (progestin)
  • Thickens cervical mucus
  • Alters endometrial lining
  • May suppress ovulation in some women

5-7 years
  • Lighter menstrual periods
  • Reduced menstrual cramps
  • Protection against endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, lower abdominal pain, and abnormal vaginal discharge for the past week. She had an IUCD inserted two months ago. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, tenderness in the lower abdomen, and cervical motion tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Incidence of pregnancy is less for women with IUCD compared to normal women

Therefore Incidence of ectopic pregnancy is also less in IUCD users

But if a woman with IUCD is pregnant—--> Rule out ectopic pregnancy

SIDE EFFECTS OF IUCD

IMMEDIATE

REMOTE
  • Cramp-like pain
  • Abnormal menstrual bleeding(most common)
  • Syncopal attack
  • Pain (2nd most common)
  • Partial or complete perforation
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
  • Spontaneous expulsion
  • Perforation of the uterus

questions.text: Which of the following natural contraception methods requires the combined use of tracking basal body temperature, monitoring cervical mucus, and recording menstrual cycle lengths to identify the fertile window?
Which of the following is not a contraindication for insertion of an Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD)?
questions.correct_answer: A. Sexually transmitted infections within 6 months.
questions.explanation:
Contraindications for insertion of IUCD
  • Pregnancy.
  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding.
  • Sexually transmitted infections:current or within 3months.
  • Severe dysmenorrhea.
  • Uterine or cervical neoplasia.
  • Trophoblastic disease.
  • Significant immunosuppression.
  • Acute pelvic infections.
  • Wilson’s disease.
  • Copper allergy.
  • Current breast cancer.
  • Severe arterial disease.

questions.text: Which of the following structures comprise DeLancey’s level 2 support?
questions.explanation:
Structures

Level I
  • Uterosacral ligaments
  • Cardinal ligaments

Level II
  • Arcus tendineus fascia
  • Pubocervical fascia
  • Rectovaginal fascia and septum

Level III
  • Perineal body
  • Superficial and deep perineal muscles
  • Fibromuscular connective tissue

questions.text: Which of the following factors primarily causes uterine prolapse by directly damaging the pelvic support structures?
questions.explanation:
Predisposing Factors

Aggravating Factors

Other Factors
  • Prolonged vaginal delivery (prolonged labour).
  • Big baby.
  • Menopause.
  • Congenital weakness (Marfan’s syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome).
  • Raised intra-abdominal pressure (e.g. COPD, constipation, obesity, etc).
  • Increasing age.
  • Multiparity.
  • Smoking (Option D).
  • Pelvic trauma.
    • Perineal tear.
    • Pudendal nerve injury.
  • Spina bifida.

questions.text: Match the following terms with their correct definitions. 1 Cystocele i The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 2 Urethrocele ii The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall 3 Enterocele iii Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall 4 Rectocele iv The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall
questions.explanation:
Cystocele

The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall

Urethrocele

The collapse of the lower 1/3rd of the anterior vaginal wall

Enterocele

The collapse of the upper 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall

Rectocele

Laxity of the middle 1/3rd of the posterior vaginal wall and rectovaginal septum

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a bulge in her vaginal area that worsens with standing for prolonged periods or straining. She has to push the bulge back into her vagina manually to relieve discomfort. Examination shows the following finding, uterine fundus lying outside the introitus with complete eversion of vaginal walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
First degree

The uterus descends downward, but the external os (opening of the cervix) remains inside the vagina.

Second degree

The uterine body remains inside the vagina while the external os protrudes outside the vaginal introitus.

Third degree 

The cervix, uterine body, and fundus descend to lie outside the introitus.

The complete uterus protrudes outside the vagina.
Procidentia Prolapse of the uterus with complete eversion of the vagina.

questions.text: On examination of a 60-year-old female with prolapse, the leading edge is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen. Which stage of the POP-Q system does this finding correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Stage 0

(Option A)

No prolapse.

Stage I (Option B)

The leading edge (most distal portion) of prolapse is more than 1 cm above the level of the hymen.

Stage II

(Option C)

The leading edge of prolapse is ≤1 cm proximal or distal to the hymen.

Stage III

(Option B)

The leading edge of the prolapse is more than 1 cm below the hymen but ≤ 2 cm less than the total vaginal length.

Stage IV

Essentially complete eversion of the total vaginal length.

questions.text: Which of the following women should seek alternative contraception methods due to absolute contraindications for combined oral contraceptive pills?

options.label: B
options.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraines without aura

options.label: C
options.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer

options.label: D
options.text: A 25-year-old woman with well-managed type1 diabetes

questions.correct_answer: C. A 40-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer
questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications of Combined Oral Contraceptives Pills (COCs)

Condition

Remarks

Pregnancy
  • COCs are strictly prohibited during pregnancy.

Circulatory Diseases (Past or Present)
  • Women who have a history of arterial or venous thrombosis, severe hypertension, stroke, or heart disease (valvular or ischemic) should avoid combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs).
  • The estrogen component in COCs can raise the risk of deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
  • This is because estrogen stimulates the liver to produce fibrinogen and clotting factors, which can contribute to clot formation.

Liver Diseases
  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) should not be used by women with active liver disease, jaundice, liver adenoma, or liver carcinoma.
  • The estrogen in COCs can increase the synthesis of hepatic angiotensinogen, which may contribute to hypertension.

Unexplained Vaginal Bleeding
  • COC use is not recommended for women with undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding.

Breast Cancer (Current or Past)
  • Women with known or suspected breast cancer should not use COCs.

Major Surgery or Prolonged Immobilisation
  • COCs are contraindicated in women who have recently undergone major surgery or experienced prolonged immobilization due to the increased risk of postoperative VTE.

Estrogen-Dependent Neoplasms
  • Women with known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasms should avoid using COCs.

Smoking and Age
  • COCs are not recommended for women older than 35 who smoke.

Diabetes with Vascular Complications
  • Women with diabetes and vascular complications should not use COCs.

Migraines with Focal Neurologic Symptoms
  • COCs should be avoided by women experiencing migraines with focal neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents a type of oral contraceptive formulation used for birth control?
Which compound is the active ingredient in Saheli tablets, a non-hormonal oral contraceptive?

Match the type of contraceptive implant with its description: Contraceptive Implant Description a. Implanon i. Consists of a single closed capsule with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years. b. Nexplanon ii. Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years. c. Jadelle iii. Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years. d. Norplant iv. Consists of six small, flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of the upper arm.
questions.explanation:
Implanon

Nexplanon

Jadelle

Norplant

Single rod implant containing etonogestrel, effective for up to 3 years.

Consists of a single closed capsule with etonogestrel and is effective for up to 3 years.

 

Consists of two rods, each containing levonorgestrel, providing contraception for up to 5 years.

 





 

Consists of six small,flexible capsules containing levonorgestrel which is implanted under the skin of upper arm.
  • Fewer adverse effects reported
  • Similar to Implanon
  • Fewer adverse effects compared to Norplant
  • Higher incidence of irregular bleeding
  • Difficulty due to multiple rods
  • Straightforward insertion and removal
  • Preloaded applicator for easier insertion and removal
  • Easier insertion and removal compared to Norplant
  • Complicated insertion and removal due to multiple rods

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the Copper T 380A intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.

options.label: B
options.text: It releases levonorgestrel to suppress ovulation and thin the endometrium.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a first-generation IUCD made of inert plastic without any medication.

options.label: D
options.text: It is effective for only 5 years and mainly used for women with heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a second-generation IUCD that releases copper ions, impairing sperm motility and viability.
questions.explanation:
Type of IUCD

Examples

Composition

MOA

Duration

Advantages

First Generation (Option C)

Lippes loop

Non medicated made of polyethylene or other polymers
  • Leads to foreign body reaction producing sterile inflammatory responses

10 years
  • Long duration
  • double "S" shape closely fit the contours of the uterine cavity, reducing the chance of expulsion

Second Generation (Copper IUCDs)

Copper T 380

Copper wire wrapped around the IUCD
  • Releases copper ions which are spermicidal
  • Impairs sperm motility and viability
  • Interfere with the capacitation of sperm

10-12 years (Option D)
  • Long duration
  • No hormones involved
  • Suitable for those who cannot use hormonal contraception

Third Generation (Hormonal IUCDs) (Option B)
  • Mirena
  • Progestasert

Levonorgestrel
  • Releases levonorgestrel (progestin)
  • Thickens cervical mucus
  • Alters endometrial lining
  • May suppress ovulation in some women

5-7 years
  • Lighter menstrual periods
  • Reduced menstrual cramps
  • Protection against endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

questions.text: A 25-year-old newly married woman wants effective contraception with a minimum failure rate. Which contraceptive method would be the most suitable for her considering both efficacy and ease of use?
